title: RBA's Kent says 'a lot more to be done' as end of Libor nears
text:
Libor is set to be phased out at the end of 2021, meaning financial institutions will need to find a new benchmark rate.

Mr Kent's comments on Wednesday echoed that of his colleague, deputy governor Guy Debelle, who noted at the same conference a year ago that the banks were not ready for a post-Libor world.

While Mr Kent was more positive on the changes the major banks were making, he emphasised the widespread use of Libor meant the whole financial system needed to do more.

"Our preliminary analysis suggests there's quite a bit of difference in terms of state of readiness," he said.

"Not surprisingly, larger internationally exposed institutions, the major banks for example, are a bit further along the path but they still have a lot more to be done.

"The bigger concern is the smaller institutions and those on the buy side, they're a bit less well prepared."

Approximately $7 trillion worth of contracts are exposed to Libor in Australia alone, with $370 trillion exposed worldwide.

"Libor is deeply embedded in global financial markets and it's used extensively here," Mr Kent said. "Australian financial institutions are exposed very substantially to contracts that reference Libor."

Mr Kent added the RBA had been working hard to make sure other benchmarks, including the Bank Bill Swap Rate (BBSW) were providing enough liquidity to be used as an alternative.

"My sense is the liquidity in that market is quite good, particularly for three and six month BBSW, but less so for one month," he said.

"There's been a lot of work to develop the new infrastructure and market practices. We've made some small tweaks to our own operations, by bringing forward our open market operations to assist with the provision of liquidity during that period."

He closed his remarks at the conference by saying the local financial system still had a long way to go when it came to transitioning away from Libor.

"[The phasing out of] Libor is fast approaching and we're already working hard with financial market participants here in Australia to get ready for that," he said. "We've taken a lot of good steps to make sure BBSW is robust but users of BBSW may want to consider whether that's the best reference rate for their products.

"Cash products and loans, they're very bespoke and each has to be negotiated individually. There's a lot of work that needs to be done."
description: RBA assistant governor Christopher Kent has urged the financial sector to do more to prepare for the end of Libor, to which Australia has an estimated $7 trillion exposure.
